sols_html:
We can consider statements I, II, III individually to which of them are true.

Statement I: f + g is Concave Up Everywhere

Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H = f + g\end{aligned}\]

Statement I is true if the second derivative of H is positive for all real numbers x. The second derivative of H is

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H'' = f'' + g''.\end{aligned}\]

However,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'' (x)\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g'' (x)\end{aligned}\]

must be positive for all real numbers (because f’ and g’ are continuous and increasing for all x), so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H'' (x)\end{aligned}\]

must be positive for all x. Statement I is true.

Statement II: f - g is Concave Up Everywhere

If we let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H = f - g\end{aligned}\]

then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H'' = f'' - g''.\end{aligned}\]

However,

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'' (x)\end{aligned}\]

could be less than

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g'' (x)\end{aligned}\]

for all real numbers, so

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H'' (x)\end{aligned}\]

may not be positive for all x. Statement II is false.

Statement III: f · g is Concave Up Everywhere

If we let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H = f \cdot g\end{aligned}\]

then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle H'' = f''g + 2f'g' + fg''.\end{aligned}\]

We know that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'' (x), g'' (x)\end{aligned}\]

are both positive for all real numbers, but we don’t necessarily have that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x), g'(x), f(x), g(x)\end{aligned}\]

are necessarily positive. So it is possible that \(f''g+fg''\) is negative and outweighs the positive term \(2f'g'\). For example, choose

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = x^2-1,\ g(x) = x^2\end{aligned}\]

Then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x) = g'(x) = 2x\end{aligned}\]

is increasing but

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f''g+2f'g'+2fg'' = (2)(x^2)+2(2x)(2x)+(x^2-1)(2) = 12x^2-2\end{aligned}\]

which is negative for small values of x (e.g. when x = 0).

Statement III is false.

The Answer

The answer is (A) I only.

statement_html:
Let f and g be functions such that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f'(x)\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle g'(x)\end{aligned}\]

are both continuous and increasing for all real numbers x. Which of the following is ALWAYS true?

f + g is concave up everywhere

f - g is concave up everywhere

f · g is concave up everywhere

I only

II only

I and II only

I and III only

I, II, and III
